The subscribers intend to decline the Lumber
Business early this Spring, and offer their Stock
on hand at reduced prices, whole sale or retail.
Any persons wishing to purchase, will find it to
their advantage to give US call, as we have a
general assortment, consisting Of Cedar and Cy-
press Shingles Of various qualities Pannel, first
ant. second common white pine Boards well sea
soned; hearts Pine and Ilemlock boards; Scant-

sizes; Poplar Plank, Boards and Scantlng; plain,
specked and curlcd Maple Boards, Plank and
scantng. Cherry scantling; inch and
half inch Walnut boards, anda variety of Other
articles not enumerated.


N. b. Any person wishing to engage in the
Lumber Business, will find it much to their ad
vantage to make application to us, as we are
disposed to sell on reasonable terms; and the
stand is we'll known to be as good as any in the
Borough,

MISCELLANEOUS.

Ran away from the subscriber, on Saturday, the
18th inst, an indented boy to the Coachmaking
business, named JOHN HALL: he went in COM
pany with boy bound to Thomas Moore. He
IS about 19 years Of age, about five feet six inches
ligh, thick set; speaks quick when spoken to;
has rather down look; light hair and light COM
plexion-had on when he went way, suit Q
blue Clothes fur hat, and boots


Whoever will secure the boy in any Jail, so
that can get him again, shall receive the above
reward; together with reasonable charges il
brought home. All persons are cautioned
against harboring said boy, at theirp peril,
PETER A. HUMPHREYS.
1Nril,,ninrtnn nnl Iun. 05--lQ at.
Twenty Dollars Reward.

be removed from under him, so that he may
stand on the bare pavement, which method
is very beneficial to his legs and feet.


LaWrencc's Treatise on tie Horse.


PULSE OF A HORSE.


In the management of sick horses great
advantage may be derived frem attending
to the state of the pulse, as we are thereby
enabled to judge of the degree of violence of
the disease, and the probability there may
be Of recovery. We are, in some meas
ure, also assisted by it in ascertaining the ma
ture of the complaint, and the application
of remedies.


In a healthy horse the pulsations are a
bout SO or 40 in minute, and may be felt
very distinctly either on the left side, or in
an artery which passes over the lower jaw
bone; in short, pulsation may be telt III eve
ry superficial artery.
When horse appears rather dull, and
pot feel properly, it is advisable to exam
inc the pulse, and if he be found to exceed
the standard OF health. impedate recourse
should be had to bleeding. BY this Timely
interference many dangerous complaints may
be prevented. When the pulse rises to SO
or 80 in minute, there is reason to be ap-
prehensive of danger; and when it exceeds
one hundred the disease frequently termi-
mates in death.


HNue's Treatise on Veterinary Medicine

THE CATHOLIC CONGREGATION Of St,
Peters Church, in the borough of Whining
ton, return their unieigned thanks to their FIX
cellencies, the late aud present Governors and
also to the Honorable gentlcmen that composed
the Senate and Assembly of the State OF Della
ware, since the year of our Lord 1922 to this
present yearof our Lord, 1872, for their kind be-
neyolence, foundcd.on Christian philanthropy,


in extending the right hand Fellowship, to their


Catholic brethren, [not in tlceting words, but in


real actions) to accomplish what was not in our


power to do; which was, to finish our church.
| and nav off the incumbTances due on the church;
! by granting us lottery, and extending II, by
( granting us two supplements one oi winch Nc
! have, The proceeds, received by the Lottery and


first supplement; which vas divided into four


different classes was received by william Larkin,


Grocer in the aforesaid Borough of Wilmington,


who acted As principal Manager for said Lottery,
and received the several sums of money obtain


ed by the sales of the aforesaid four different


classes Of said l.ottcry-whIch money, the said


" illiam Iarkln illegally holds from us, the Ma.


nagers for the Congregation OF St Peters
! Church, although VIC have repeatedly called on
, the said william farkin during the time and term
of near five years from the commencement o
the first class Of the said Lottery And for hi:
/ SO Illegally Withholding the money obtained by


the sales of the aforesaid Lottery, we have


suit at Law against the said William Larkn; a
we could not get a settlement from him, but a
u busive language and insolcnce, every time We
e applied TO him for such settlement


e We, the Managers of St. Peters Church, Civ
:. the public in general notice, that we discharg
: the aforesaid William I.arkin from our emplo
e and forbid him to transact any business as Ma
: nagcr, Agent or Broker for any concern, direct
f ly or indirectly, belonging to ST. Peters Church
v in the borough of Wilmington, state of Dels
: ware-And also give the public notice that W
n will not acknowledge nor abide by any transa,
= ton done for the Church by any person or pc
!. sons, unless legally empowered by the Manal
=. ers

In The "Wimingtcnian' OF the iotn INST,
very scurrilous publication appeared W.
the signatures OF Peter Pierce, Bernard M
f;u;gsn. bernard M.Cann and John Durnin,
self.stvlcd Trustees of the Catholic Church,
| in Wilmington, in which my character mas
] heen uniustly assaled, and most wantonly
slandered. I feel it duty owe TO myself
and my friends, to rcpel the unauthorized
base and unfounded charges made ny those

Itmay be vecollected, that on application

in 1922, authorized the raising by Lottery,
forthe use of the Church, and payment OF

in Phil .delphia. In conformity with the
provisions of the law, the Managers pro

them. After riis period the Managers u.
niteG, in opinlor, that one OF rhem should
sign the Tickets, and receive and make pay
ment of prizes Unfortunately for me, or,
as the self-created Trustees would have It,
for the Church, was selected tor that pur-
pose, the residue OF the Managers giving me
their bond OF indemnity against any loss IN
the performance of that duty


The scheme of this Lottery was sold to

Note, and payment Of her debts the tull a
mount aud upwards, say sixteen hundred
and FIVE dollars aud fourteen cents. The
! Third class Of this Lottery, was subsequent
" under the direction of Patrick Higgins,
and conducted by him, and many of the TICK


cts in that class remained unsold. The pri-
zcs in that class was called on for, and OBJ
liged to pay; by my SIGNING, ] was pledged
TO redeem them, On Hope failing in his en-
ragemcnts the Fourth class was sold to


Nrssrs Yates and M.lntyre. The money
received for thr clas, drawn BY them, ace
cording to contract, was applied (and paid
to the deficiency Of the Sd class, conducted
j BY Patrick Higgins. All of these facts,
remain ready ard willing to make appear IN


defence of the suit t2O e.rnhmgty &hoken Of,


but 7thieh has never been commenced, altho


SO boldly asserted.

know o. ne powers they possess to grant te

pect.

AGENTS

STABLES.


Narrow stalls are source Of great incon
venience and danger to horse when he
turns round in them. In the course of my
practice, have met with several cases OF
diseased spines or back bones from this
cause only. Injuries Of this kind are gener-
ally beyond relief, IN which account they
point out very forcibly the necessity pre-
vention.


When the horse is required to turn round
in a narrow stall, his own experience OF his
situation would teach him to move back
wards out of it, but the groom prevents him
from so doing, by standing close behind him,
and urging him, either by a Threatening tone
Of voice, or whip, 10 turn instantaneously
ia a space considerably shorter than his own
body.


Although by exerting the utmost ficxihil
ity of his frame, the animal may, perhaps,
perform this motion daily without injury, he
is, nevertheless, exposed to an accident
which may in an instant render him tor tie
future totally unserviceable.


The width of the STALL therefore, should
be at least six feet, the length nine feet
This will enable the horse to stretch out his
limbs when he is lying down, which great
relief to him when he is tatigued.


The manner in which the stall is usually
paved, is equally productive OF bad effects.
The surface is generally formed with de-
scent from the head of the stall backwards,
with a view to let the urine run off from the
litter. Thus the horse stands continually
up hill, by which position he naturally be-
canes so much fatigued, that he may be said
to have performed his work before ne is out
OF the stable. For the lgaments OF his
joints and flexor muscles of his legs, are
thereby perpetually extended. If the read
er will stand for few minutes, with his
toes higher than his heels, the pain he will
feel in the calves of his legs will soon con
vince him of the truth of this remark.-
Hence, when the horse is not eating, he al
WAYS endeavors to find his level, either BY
standing across the stall. or else as far back
as his halter will permit, SO that his hind
legs may meet the ascent of the other side
OF the channel. But the greatest mischiefs
which arise from this mode OF constructing
she pavement consist in obligng the horse
Co stand with his fore legs farther under
and out Of perpendicular direction, By
which position, he not only acquires habit
of leaning forward, but also becomes LA
ble to contraction il The heels Of bis feet
by the weight being principally on the toes
at moreover promotes an inclination Y
swelling in the hind legs as wen as bein!
frequently the cause Of his body slipping
backwards in the stall when he lies dawn
SO that being atthe utmost extent OF his hal
ter, he has not the power of rising again o.
his legs, for want of free use of his head an
neck.


The ground surface of the stall, therefore
should be perfectly level, and paved Wit
hard bricks A conductor for the urine ma
be obtained by means of drain passing fror
the centre backwards under the pavemen
49,, Af 40
should sink somewhat lewer than the othe
parts of it, and the entrance to the drain COY
cred with an iron CRATE about six inche
square


1t will be found advantageous to construc
the manger in such manner that it may +
removed by sliding into the wall, SO tn.
when the horse has eaten his grain he ma
have nothing else to bite at when the groo
is cleaning him, from which habit hers
sometimes become crib-biters.


The racks are best made of cast iron,
wooden rack slaves frequently introdul
splinters into the lips during the action
gathering the hay.


The door of the stable should be at lea
seven feet in height, which will render Il
horse less liable to strike his hsad again
the upper part of it in passing through it.


WATER.


With regard to water, horses general
prefer that which is soft and even thick al
muddy. Soft water should therefore alwa
be given to them if possible. The quaint
should be proportional to the labour whi
the animal undergoes, for ifhe sweats muc
he will consequently require more to rep;
the consumption of the fluids of his body.
It is customary in hunting stables, to wal
the water before che morse drinks it, this
a very bad practice, as it renders him |
BILE to be grpcd whenever he drinksit
any other state. 1t certainly is not pruat
20 give much cold water to horse vii
he is heated with exercise, but other
rods may be found when he may dri
it with safety. Grooms have a foolish h
it of galloping horses Immediately af
drinking: with the intention of warming
water in their stomachs. BY these unnec
sary precautions, il would appear that C
water was both unnatural and prejudicial
the animal; but it can only become so fl
his being rendered irritable and tender
the absurd modes with which he is trea
in his domesticated state.


flashing horses 4vhen 79arm in7urlon


Innkeepers and coach-masters would
it their interest to prevent the abomin;
custom of washing horses over their wi
bodies Immediately after having gone ST.

full articles.article:
The subscribers intend to decline the Lumber
Business early this Spring, and offer their Stock
on hand at reduced prices, whole sale or retail.
Any persons wishing to purchase, will find it to
their advantage to give US call, as we have a
general assortment, consisting Of Cedar and Cy-
press Shingles Of various qualities Pannel, first
ant. second common white pine Boards well sea
soned; hearts Pine and Ilemlock boards; Scant-
ling and Joist of various qualities, lengths and

specked and curlcd Maple Boards, Plank and
scantng. Cherry scantling; inch and
half inch Walnut boards, anda variety of Other
articles not enumerated.


N. b. Any person wishing to engage in the

vantage to make application to us, as we are

stand is we'll known to be as good as any in the
Borough,


EZRA HOOPES,
JOSEPH THOMAS.

full articles.headline: Twenty Dollars Reward.
full articles.article:
Ran away from the subscriber, on Saturday, the
18th inst, an indented boy to the Coachmaking
business, named JOHN HALL: he went in COM
pany with boy bound to Thomas Moore. He
IS about 19 years Of age, about five feet six inches
ligh, thick set; speaks quick when spoken to;
has rather down look; light hair and light COM
plexion-had on when he went way, suit Q
blue Clothes fur hat, and boots


Whoever will secure the boy in any Jail, so
that can get him again, shall receive the above
reward; together with reasonable charges il
brought home. All persons are cautioned
against harboring said boy, at theirp peril,
PETER A. HUMPHREYS.
1Nril,,ninrtnn nnl Iun. 05--lQ at.

be removed from under him, so that he may
stand on the bare pavement, which method
is very beneficial to his legs and feet.


LaWrencc's Treatise on tie Horse.


PULSE OF A HORSE.


In the management of sick horses great
advantage may be derived frem attending
to the state of the pulse, as we are thereby
enabled to judge of the degree of violence of
the disease, and the probability there may
be Of recovery. We are, in some meas
ure, also assisted by it in ascertaining the ma
ture of the complaint, and the application
of remedies.


In a healthy horse the pulsations are a
bout SO or 40 in minute, and may be felt
very distinctly either on the left side, or in
an artery which passes over the lower jaw
bone; in short, pulsation may be telt III eve
ry superficial artery.
When horse appears rather dull, and
pot feel properly, it is advisable to exam
inc the pulse, and if he be found to exceed
the standard OF health. impedate recourse
should be had to bleeding. BY this Timely
interference many dangerous complaints may
be prevented. When the pulse rises to SO
or 80 in minute, there is reason to be ap-
prehensive of danger; and when it exceeds
one hundred the disease frequently termi-
mates in death.


HNue's Treatise on Veterinary Medicine

THE CATHOLIC CONGREGATION Of St,
Peters Church, in the borough of Whining
ton, return their unieigned thanks to their FIX
cellencies, the late aud present Governors and
also to the Honorable gentlcmen that composed
the Senate and Assembly of the State OF Della
ware, since the year of our Lord 1922 to this
present yearof our Lord, 1872, for their kind be-
neyolence, foundcd.on Christian philanthropy,


in extending the right hand Fellowship, to their


Catholic brethren, [not in tlceting words, but in


real actions) to accomplish what was not in our


power to do; which was, to finish our church.
| and nav off the incumbTances due on the church;
! by granting us lottery, and extending II, by
( granting us two supplements one oi winch Nc
! have, The proceeds, received by the Lottery and


first supplement; which vas divided into four


different classes was received by william Larkin,


Grocer in the aforesaid Borough of Wilmington,


who acted As principal Manager for said Lottery,
and received the several sums of money obtain


ed by the sales of the aforesaid four different


classes Of said l.ottcry-whIch money, the said


" illiam Iarkln illegally holds from us, the Ma.


nagers for the Congregation OF St Peters
! Church, although VIC have repeatedly called on
, the said william farkin during the time and term
of near five years from the commencement o
the first class Of the said Lottery And for hi:
/ SO Illegally Withholding the money obtained by


the sales of the aforesaid Lottery, we have


suit at Law against the said William Larkn; a
we could not get a settlement from him, but a
u busive language and insolcnce, every time We
e applied TO him for such settlement


e We, the Managers of St. Peters Church, Civ
:. the public in general notice, that we discharg
: the aforesaid William I.arkin from our emplo
e and forbid him to transact any business as Ma
: nagcr, Agent or Broker for any concern, direct
f ly or indirectly, belonging to ST. Peters Church
v in the borough of Wilmington, state of Dels
: ware-And also give the public notice that W
n will not acknowledge nor abide by any transa,
= ton done for the Church by any person or pc
!. sons, unless legally empowered by the Manal
=. ers


' PETER PIERCE,
3 BERNARD M'GUIGEN
BERNARD M'CANN,
e JOHN DURNIN.
= Feb. Ia, 1927. 22-ltp.

full articles.headline: 10 THE PUBLIC.
full articles.article:
~ 4 L4kS = ~ 4S>~~


In The "Wimingtcnian' OF the iotn INST,
very scurrilous publication appeared W.
the signatures OF Peter Pierce, Bernard M
f;u;gsn. bernard M.Cann and John Durnin,
self.stvlcd Trustees of the Catholic Church,
| in Wilmington, in which my character mas
] heen uniustly assaled, and most wantonly
slandered. I feel it duty owe TO myself
and my friends, to rcpel the unauthorized
base and unfounded charges made ny those
calumniators, and expose them to that con-
tempt they merit by exhibiting to the pup
lie statement of the facts connected with
the Lottery case alluded to- as briefly as prac-
| ticable, with comment, from which they
NAV be enabled to form their Judgments.


Itmay be vecollected, that on application
of the Trustees of St. Peters Church, at
Wilmington, the Legislature OF Delaware
in 1922, authorized the raising by Lottery,
forthe use of the Church, and payment OF
debts, the sum of three thousand dollars, lo-
yer and beyond all expenses); anc III ina.
law named certain Managers to superihtehd
the Lottery; some in Wilmington ana some
in Phil .delphia. In conformity with the
provisions of the law, the Managers pro
ceeded TO discharge the trust conhdeo 20
them. After riis period the Managers u.
niteG, in opinlor, that one OF rhem should
sign the Tickets, and receive and make pay
ment of prizes Unfortunately for me, or,
as the self-created Trustees would have It,
for the Church, was selected tor that pur-
pose, the residue OF the Managers giving me
their bond OF indemnity against any loss IN
the performance of that duty


The scheme of this Lottery was sold to
Thomas Hope, Broker. by and with the
consent Of the Ma1tgers, for the sum of
three thousand dollars-to be drawn in Six
classes, ayable $500 at the drawing of each
class. Cuder that ARRANGEMENT Mr.. Hope
went on, and drew two classes, For those
two classes paid the Church in cash and
Note, and payment Of her debts the tull a
mount aud upwards, say sixteen hundred
and FIVE dollars aud fourteen cents. The
! Third class Of this Lottery, was subsequent
" under the direction of Patrick Higgins,
and conducted by him, and many of the TICK


cts in that class remained unsold. The pri-
zcs in that class was called on for, and OBJ
liged to pay; by my SIGNING, ] was pledged
TO redeem them, On Hope failing in his en-
ragemcnts the Fourth class was sold to


Nrssrs Yates and M.lntyre. The money
received for thr clas, drawn BY them, ace
cording to contract, was applied (and paid
to the deficiency Of the Sd class, conducted
j BY Patrick Higgins. All of these facts,
remain ready ard willing to make appear IN


defence of the suit t2O e.rnhmgty &hoken Of,


but 7thieh has never been commenced, altho


SO boldly asserted.


AS 10 the dcnunci4ton of my services, by
those "Tiustees". il is truly ridiculous.


know o. ne powers they possess to grant te


me- Nh a270trS Arc from higher and
, more resrsctsplr source. Those men need


erplovnieut themselves, and they will pro-
baiiv receive it, 81 that Kind in legal way
not comfortable othem. A part OF the tlnds


Of the Church would, 10 doubt, be very con
vcateu "a 0pr 'e,cntlemen Trustees" but


which . i hnpel the good sense of the coli-


gregaton will prevent them from banding


afd Very nn1artunate indeed would 1t be tol


the Church, to confide bcr concerns in such


hands, 79ho Lave not sufficient discretion Il


conduct their own affairs. ] would observe


that no dissatisfaction would have arose, bu


tor two disorganlzing members, one ot whom
J. undertook TO perform part III the Lottery
d which his incapacity unhtted him tor, where
; by he was abandoned; and he did not real


60 rich harvest as his fancy led him to cx


pect.


would further remark, that the second


IS a certain nondescript. pcttitogglng Doc


tor, who is every thing by turns and nothing
- long affecting to be Catholic, and who

~ has seen sowing Giscord aud dissention a
,e mong the members since he came tn WI
+ mington. From whence he came, or who h
= is, God only knows. 1t has been said h
Is formerly resided in Lancaster, but for wha
le he left Lancaster, whether by d0y or nigh
4, for the safety Of his carcdSc, or by the advic
he of tseeipe hoHrSt ycomen, know not.


r. am attached TO the Catholic church


which affords me satistacton; and feel


pride in promoting the interests OF tn


Church; and do hope the congregation wi
= lie on their guard against the tricks attempt
st. I'd to be practsed on them by such an un
g 2rincipied renegade.


X feel consciousness Of the correctnes
nd Of the course pursued BY NE in regard to tn
20 Church, aud that it has not only been jus
IA and horourabe, but that instead of a gai'
MS have sustained a ieSs, by my attention I
y her concerns, which can make appear 81
y, tistactorly TO any unprejudlced mind.


:" VIM. LARKIN.
~ - Wilmington, Fcb. 10Th, 1s27.-22--4tp.
N NI,IIop NNopia1

full articles.headline:
THE FARMER.

From the New-England Farmer.
MANAGEMENT AND DISEASES OF


HORSES.
full articles.article:
STABLES.


Narrow stalls are source Of great incon
venience and danger to horse when he
turns round in them. In the course of my
practice, have met with several cases OF
diseased spines or back bones from this
cause only. Injuries Of this kind are gener-
ally beyond relief, IN which account they
point out very forcibly the necessity pre-
vention.


When the horse is required to turn round
in a narrow stall, his own experience OF his
situation would teach him to move back
wards out of it, but the groom prevents him
from so doing, by standing close behind him,
and urging him, either by a Threatening tone
Of voice, or whip, 10 turn instantaneously
ia a space considerably shorter than his own
body.


Although by exerting the utmost ficxihil
ity of his frame, the animal may, perhaps,
perform this motion daily without injury, he
is, nevertheless, exposed to an accident
which may in an instant render him tor tie
future totally unserviceable.


The width of the STALL therefore, should
be at least six feet, the length nine feet
This will enable the horse to stretch out his
limbs when he is lying down, which great
relief to him when he is tatigued.


The manner in which the stall is usually
paved, is equally productive OF bad effects.
The surface is generally formed with de-
scent from the head of the stall backwards,
with a view to let the urine run off from the
litter. Thus the horse stands continually
up hill, by which position he naturally be-
canes so much fatigued, that he may be said
to have performed his work before ne is out
OF the stable. For the lgaments OF his
joints and flexor muscles of his legs, are
thereby perpetually extended. If the read
er will stand for few minutes, with his
toes higher than his heels, the pain he will
feel in the calves of his legs will soon con
vince him of the truth of this remark.-
Hence, when the horse is not eating, he al
WAYS endeavors to find his level, either BY
standing across the stall. or else as far back
as his halter will permit, SO that his hind
legs may meet the ascent of the other side
OF the channel. But the greatest mischiefs
which arise from this mode OF constructing
she pavement consist in obligng the horse
Co stand with his fore legs farther under
and out Of perpendicular direction, By
which position, he not only acquires habit
of leaning forward, but also becomes LA
ble to contraction il The heels Of bis feet
by the weight being principally on the toes
at moreover promotes an inclination Y
swelling in the hind legs as wen as bein!
frequently the cause Of his body slipping
backwards in the stall when he lies dawn
SO that being atthe utmost extent OF his hal
ter, he has not the power of rising again o.
his legs, for want of free use of his head an
neck.


The ground surface of the stall, therefore
should be perfectly level, and paved Wit
hard bricks A conductor for the urine ma
be obtained by means of drain passing fror
the centre backwards under the pavemen
49,, Af 40
should sink somewhat lewer than the othe
parts of it, and the entrance to the drain COY
cred with an iron CRATE about six inche
square


1t will be found advantageous to construc
the manger in such manner that it may +
removed by sliding into the wall, SO tn.
when the horse has eaten his grain he ma
have nothing else to bite at when the groo
is cleaning him, from which habit hers
sometimes become crib-biters.


The racks are best made of cast iron,
wooden rack slaves frequently introdul
splinters into the lips during the action
gathering the hay.


The door of the stable should be at lea
seven feet in height, which will render Il
horse less liable to strike his hsad again
the upper part of it in passing through it.


WATER.


With regard to water, horses general
prefer that which is soft and even thick al
muddy. Soft water should therefore alwa
be given to them if possible. The quaint
should be proportional to the labour whi
the animal undergoes, for ifhe sweats muc
he will consequently require more to rep;
the consumption of the fluids of his body.
It is customary in hunting stables, to wal
the water before che morse drinks it, this
a very bad practice, as it renders him |
BILE to be grpcd whenever he drinksit
any other state. 1t certainly is not pruat
20 give much cold water to horse vii
he is heated with exercise, but other
rods may be found when he may dri
it with safety. Grooms have a foolish h
it of galloping horses Immediately af
drinking: with the intention of warming
water in their stomachs. BY these unnec
sary precautions, il would appear that C
water was both unnatural and prejudicial
the animal; but it can only become so fl
his being rendered irritable and tender
the absurd modes with which he is trea
in his domesticated state.


flashing horses 4vhen 79arm in7urlon


Innkeepers and coach-masters would
it their interest to prevent the abomin;
custom of washing horses over their wi
bodies Immediately after having gone ST.

Useful hroherties Of Ceiandine.

ring g-worms, destroys warts and cures the
itch.
